job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I worked with some great people!
cons: Unfortunately, the organization was very hierarchical and frustrating to work for. HR was a mess and couldn't retain staff. The whole school is unable to retain staff because the pay is so low. I felt unappreciated and my work, which was fundamental to the running of the department, was unseens and unacknowledged.

job_title: Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
Great, amazing people to work with. Students are even better, and some of the most funny, most genuine people you'll ever meet (Outside of the occasional bad egg)

Also very easy to commute to off the trains. 
Decent benefits.
cons:
Pay is a joke, I've heard stories of them lying on interviews, they will lowball you hard on your salary.

Management (generally) is...terrible. Not understanding what you do, how to improve, will expect the world for you.

This is the type of place that will throw the word "Family environment" as an excuse to make you work extra for no gain.

review_title: Experience is highly dependent on department
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Decent pay, good benefits and good PTO
cons: Management is extremely uneven, employee experiences vary widely dependent on the department. Very little room for career advancement or even professional development, even before pandemic departments were stretched too thin. A very privileged attitude of if you don't like it you can leave, without any institutional reflection on why so many people are unsatisfied in their positions. This leads to high turnover and a lack of institutional memory in the positions that are responsible for most of the day-to-day work and a huge loss of productivity.

review_title: Wage Suppression and Lack of Career Advancement
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
There are a lot of really great colleagues and faculty working across a broad range of fields; so there's no shortage of interesting people to engage with. 

Culture used to be a pro, but due to the cons of SVA morale has been lowering and lowering and the culture is not what it once was. 

Departments at the school are fairly provincial, and somewhat function autonomously, so experiences may vary. 

I'm sure there are exceptions but in my experience there was very minimal micromanagement so long as you perform your duties reliably. 

In my experience there was very little demand to work after hours or put in overtime, so work life balance was good. There's an occasional Saturday for open houses and such, but you get days off to compensate.

The health insurance is fairly decent, but over the past few years there's been a push by the school to get employees to enroll in a less generous benefits package, and they've rolled back other benefits like 401k matching. 

Art school students generally keep things interesting as well, to say the least.
cons:
SVA consistently offers wages below market rate and aggressively engages in wage suppression. Even if your direct manager/supervisor supports a wage increase or advocates for a promotion you will almost always get rebuffed by HR. 

HR is problematic on a number of levels, not least of all that they regularly make payroll mistakes. You must constantly make sure you are being paid correctly. An example would be double charging taxes/benefits. 

HR also clearly and consistently functions in a manner to protect the school. They rarely take grievances seriously, and if they entertain a legitimate complaint, they engage in gaslighting by downplaying or denying any provided evidence. Complaints range from racism, sexism, etc. Several colleagues over the years quit as a direct result of this.

Upper level management are usually in the position due to a relationship, rather than experience or merit.

job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in New York, NY
pros:
Get to Travel if you are interested in going to different places in the US.
Build up points on personal accounts for travel.
Per diem is a good amount.
Get to work with students who are actively interested in Art.
cons:
Work-life balance is rough due to the travel season from September to January.
Management can be difficult.

job_title: Help Desk Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The benefits package is good. Generous time off/vacation. Creative atmosphere.
cons: Abysmal pay and very few opportunities for growth.

job_title: Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Friendly work environment and everyone seems welcoming in what they do at SVA.
cons:
Things get done until something bad happens.
Some managers don't allow you work cross-functionally with another department to support.
HR are slow to resolve concerns with supervisors and side with them. They're not neutral.

review_title: An OK entry job, but get out fast
job_title: Admissions in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work for artists who want supplemental income to freelance, or recent graduates looking to build their resume. You will work with a lot of cool and creative people. Access to a lot of great resources including free classes, lab access, free museums and movie passes. Pretty good health care, 401k. Will pay your tuition if you are accepted into a grad program at SVA and at some other schools.
cons: Management is a nightmare. It is micromanaging in the extreme. Incompetent people are often promoted simply because they don't rock the boat. It is almost impossible to remove a bad manager from their position and they often sink entire departments. The pay is insane for the hours worked and it's not uncommon to be asked to do overtime with no pay. HR is a joke and has never responded to my calls or emails in two years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Working with some incredible students, access to equipment and studio space
cons:
Just about everything else. Working in the photography department is like living in the movie Mean Girls. Everyone is exceptionally passive aggressive, gossipy, and generally not very interesting or good people. They gang up and force out anyone who is different, or attempts to show any shred of individuality or personality. 

There is absolutely zero communications skills in this department. Instead, if an employee or co worker is having issues, or doing something wrong/incorrect/inappropriate the official course of action is to document it, and then present it at a later date. Instead of, you know, actually talking to the person who is having the issue, addressing the problem and discussing it, then allowing it to resolve. 

The photography department chair is nothing more than a grown up rich kid having his fun running a photo department. His vision is aimless and not thought out properly. His involvement in the actual happenings in the department is minimal at best, except when someone would like to bypass management. 

Do not work here, ever.

review_title: Sva is good but you need to work to make it work.
job_title: Instructor, Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros:
For faculty, working at SVA is good in that you get paid well to perform when you are teaching.  The students are excellent and engaging and the facilities are excellent. Most teachers at SVA are leaders in their respective careers.

Teachers do not have office hours, committe work, or departmental duties.
cons:
Everyone who teaches is an adjunct at SVA. Teachers are not paid for preperation time, student contact outside the scope of class, or grading. Because of this, teachers are well paid for their classes but since it's so little time (6-12 hours usually) it's impossible to make a living solely as a teacher.  As a result, most teachers are professionals in their careers and usually work outside their teaching duties.


SVA is an extremely entrepreneurial place so teachers needs to constantly stay current and propose novel ideas.

job_title: Photography Department in New York, NY
pros: Students are great, faculty are great
cons: The general confusing nature of the college may result in this being a bad career move (test: go to their web site, and try to find the email address for the building maintenance department, or really, any information that would be useful--you probably won't find it).  The state of the web site is reflective of the state of the college; departments badly managed, no central support; the department I was in was so nonsupportive that asking a simple question of management was seen as weakness; so, in effect, one can be paralyzed from doing the job hired for.  If you are in a current position and getting relevant experience at all, please consider this college very carefully; you may find yourself in a bad state...ask questions of the department head; really try to see the environment, and get a clear sense of what your tasks will be..and note that these can change without warning, or without clear communication;

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Creative and dynamic in some areas and departments. There are some very innovative people to some extent and the growth of the potential is important because of enormous financial means.
cons: Racial and class stratification! There is a culture of entitlement deeply embedded into the minds of people, whether it is power and greed.  Underpaid staff besides the chair persons.  The lack of assistance by some staffs to busy about doing their own things. To increase profit is the primary goal for the owners and the effectiveness is still not long and lasting. The human resources are corrupted.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The students make it all worth going to work.  The creative energy at the school makes it easy to get up and go to work each day.  Not micromanaged so there is room to be creative at work and suggest new strategies to the administration and faculty.  Great benefits and time off.
cons: Pay isn't great and offers little room to grow.  There is no step system or simple way to increase in salary even when going well beyond the job description.

review_title: Internship in SVA's International Students Office
job_title: Internship in New York, NY
pros: Even as a lower-level employee like an intern manning the front desk area, I never felt unappreciated. I had friendly, generous colleagues, cushy office space, and flexible hours. The small, diverse office group is always very welcoming and considerate.
cons: Any and all cons came from students delaying on submitting important documents, causing some traffic within the office that can get hectic. Traffic is especially common during lunch hours, when there are less student advisors in the office, and close to closing time.

job_title: Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Passionate students & lower level staff, good benefits (401k, health insurance, ability to take free/reduced rate classes)
cons: Low pay, poor work/life balance, upper level management seems apathetic to the needs or interests of students, poor communication and cooperation between departments, it's a major hassle to take off earned vacation days

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I really learned a lot here.  I really honed my skills and became far better at what I do.  This job definitely prepared me for my future roles.  Also, I met and became close friends with a lot of wonderful people.
cons: People don't always have appropriate boundaries.  Free time is not always respected.  They really don't understand the difference between a true emergency and "the boss really wants it".

cons: leadership was shaky at times, pay/upward mobility is not great

review_title: Departments vary in quality, teaching generally better than admin roles BUT NO TENURE

review_title: Good quality of life, bad pay
